items.title: Upgrade Sphinx version
items.body:
rstcheck requires Sphinx 1.4.9.
There is already Sphinx 2.4.4 now. I cannot include rstcheck into my package, since it conflicts with the Sphinx version.

items.title: rstcheck cannot find config when called from ALE vim plugin
items.body:
The [ALE plugin](https://github.com/w0rp/ale) performs linting on the fly and writes out the content of the buffer to be checked to a temporary file that can be anywhere (on macOS, it's location is something like `/private/var/folders/ll/rgszt4s525s2xtv8rr60mqz40000gn/T/nvim1JCyX8/3`). Then, ALE calls `rstcheck <tempfile>` with the location of the original file as the current working directory. In typical usage, that working directory will be the `docs` folder of a Python project, and contain `rstcheck` configuration in `setup.cfg`. However, `rstcheck` will never see this configuration, because when searching for config files, it walks up from the temporary file location, not from current working directory.

I would propose adding a command line option `--config` with the following behavior:

If `--config` points to a file (of any name), that file is used as a config file directly. If it points to a folder, then `rstcheck` walks up from the folder to check for the standard config files (`.rstcheck.cfg`, `setup.cfg`). The location of the temporary file would be ignored when `--config` is passed. The ALE plugin would have to be modified to pass the current working directory to `--config`.

An alternative solution would be the following:

If no config file is found when walking all the way to `/` from the file location, also try to walk up from the current working directory. This would require no change on ALE's side. However, it might lead to some unpredictable results: on some systems, the temporary folder might be inside the users home directory, and they might have a `~/.rstcheck.cfg file ` that would take precedence over the "project" files.

Either solution is relatively easy to implement, and I'd be able to make a pull request if you decide what the best way forward is.

items.title: Add tests to source tarball
items.body:
I'd like to submit this linter to packaging systems, and have a working .spec at

https://build.opensuse.org/package/view_file/home:jayvdb:coala:python3-bears/python-rstcheck/python-rstcheck.spec?expand=1

Source tarballs helps achieve this without hacks like downloading the tests from github.

items.title: Incompatiblitily with sphinx 1.8
items.body:
This code is causing problems `sphinx.errors.ApplicationError: Source directory and destination directory cannot be identical`
https://github.com/myint/rstcheck/blob/0bcb5101493063d49235d5dc55b08b2ecfd6a9ee/rstcheck.py#L892

Ref https://github.com/rtfd/readthedocs.org/pull/4631

items.title: Verify usage of `multiprocessing.Pool`
items.body:
The parallel processing part is fine, but the comment below doesn't look right. Note the comment about avoiding mutating state. I'm not sure if it is true. And how about the `else` case?

https://github.com/myint/rstcheck/blob/67bc30dd337ef336d20cd180e3a10ad625332d3c/rstcheck.py#L917-L928

items.title: Ignore specific errors
items.body:
Hi, is possible to do this?

Sometimes there is some false positives errors that I would like to suppress. 

I would glad to help if this is possible :)

items.title: If no specific file/files are mentioned in the args, check all `.rst` files recursively
items.body: I find it tedious to use [``find``](http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/find.1.html) to search for all `.rst` files and pass them to ``rstcheck``.  I think it would be nice if ``rstcheck`` could check all `.rst` files in the current working directory and sub-directorates recursively. Or perhaps do that if the argument is a directory, accepting relative paths (e.g. ``rstcheck .``).

items.title: Allow setting the report level through the config file
items.body:
I'd like to suggest allowing to set report level through the config file such that the following config will act as if the `--report error` parameter was passed to `rstcheck`:
```cfg
[rstcheck]
report=error
```
Thanks!

items.title: Allow config in a setup.cfg file
items.body:
Programs like `pydocstyle` or `flake8` allow users to put their configs in the same file called `setup.cfg`.
Because I am often working with those and rstcheck, I am a bit annoyed about having to write my config to a special file only for rstcheck.

Would it be possible to have a such an option? If so I'd like to try to submit patches to provide this feature.

setup.cfg example
```cfg
[pycodestyle]
exclude = ...
[pydocstyle]
match-dir = ...
[flake8]
exclude = ...
jobs = ...
# It would be nice to also have:
[rstcheck]
#Your configs here
```

items.title: Config does not allow ignoring substitutions
items.body: Substitutions cannot be ignored via .rstcheck.cfg file. We should allow configuration any options that are available via the CLI to also be configured via config file.

items.title: Detect and reject markdown-style links in RST
items.body: At coala we've found it quite common for people to accidentally use markdown syntax links in RST, and no tool currently detects this, and reviewers also dont pick it up.

items.title: Unit test errors on PyPy3
items.body:
PyPy3 2.6 and PyPy3-3.3 both have unit test errors.

```
$ ./test_rstcheck.py
........FF.F..........s...

======================================================================
FAIL: test_check_json (__main__.Tests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 78, in test_check_json
    """\
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 19, in assert_lines_equal
    self.assertEqual(set(line_numbers), set(dict(results)))
AssertionError: Items in the first set but not the second:
7

Items in the second set but not the first:
5

======================================================================
FAIL: test_check_json_with_bad_ignore (__main__.Tests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 127, in test_check_json_with_bad_ignore
    """\
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 19, in assert_lines_equal
    self.assertEqual(set(line_numbers), set(dict(results)))
AssertionError: Items in the first set but not the second:
7

Items in the second set but not the first:
5

======================================================================
FAIL: test_check_json_with_unmatched_ignores_only (__main__.Tests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 110, in test_check_json_with_unmatched_ignores_only
    """\
  File "./test_rstcheck.py", line 19, in assert_lines_equal
    self.assertEqual(set(line_numbers), set(dict(results)))
AssertionError: Items in the first set but not the second:
7

Items in the second set but not the first:
5

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 26 tests in 0.706s

FAILED (failures=3, skipped=1)
```
https://travis-ci.org/jayvdb/rstcheck/builds/213974625

items.title: sphinx unknown directive "Highlight"
items.body:
same as #1 , rstcheck failing this:

```
.. Highlight:: shell

============
Contributing
============
```
with 
```
rstcheck --report 2 *.rst
CONTRIBUTING.rst:1: (ERROR/3) Unknown directive type "Highlight".
(pyv35-lite) ➜  cobrapy git:(feat/ravn-mat) 
```
perhaps one could have some --ignore-directives flag to auto drop all these..

items.title: UnicodeWarning: Unicode equal comparison failed
Include MIT/Expat license text
items.body: It would be nice to include the [MIT/Expat](http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT) license text (also in MANIFEST.in). This is a prerequisite for Debian packaging.

items.title: Ignore substitutions
items.body:
I'm using standard  Sphinx substitutions (see [docs](http://sphinx-doc.org/markup/inline.html#substitutions)) like this:

``` rst
Hello World
===========

Last build date |today|
```

But it raises error `docs/index.rst|16 error| Undefined substitution referenced: "today".`
It would be nice to be able ignore substitution.

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError in setup.py reading README.rst
items.body:
```
   File "setup.py", line 24, in <module>
     long_description=readme.read(),
   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
     return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
 UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 2488: ordinal not in range(128)
```

items.title: .rstcheck.cfg to INDEX.rst
items.body: It would be nice to describe in INDEX.rst work .rstcheck.cfg. Because that not all people will watch the source code. I can do it if you do not mind.

items.title: [Sphinx] Cross-referencing arbitrary locations shows an error
items.body:
Hello,

I added standard reST labels to rst document as described in sphinx instruction (http://sphinx-doc.org/markup/inline.html#cross-referencing-arbitrary-locations)

My example:

``` rst
.. _http-protocol:

HTTP протокол
=============
```

but get an error:
`docs/net/http.rst:1: (INFO/1) Hyperlink target "http-protocol" is not referenced.`

It's probably a bug.

items.title: Error in "code-block" directive:      maximum 1 argument(s) allowed, 2 supplied.
items.body:
Hello, I'm trying to set the arguments in the directives, but get an error:

``` python
.. code-block:: python
    :linenos:

    print("Hello!")
```

``` bash

$ rstcheck source/hello.rst
source/hello.rst:87: (ERROR/3) Error in "code-block" directive:     
maximum 1 argument(s) allowed, 2 supplied.                                                      

.. code-block:: python
    :linenos:

    print("Hello!")                                                     
```

Without `:linenos:` work OK

items.title: Autodoc extension for Sphinx
items.body:
Can you add the directives for the autodoc extension to the ignore list?  Syntastic is always flagging these directives as errors.  Or is there a way to have rstcheck recognize them as valid directives?
http://sphinx-doc.org/ext/autodoc.html

items.title: sphinx, unknown directives
items.body:
Trying to use this with sphinx, but it throws errors on most directives, e.g. 

```
Unknown directive type "toctree".
```

Is there a way to configure rstcheck to pick up the enabled sphinx directives?
